editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

titleStmt.title: The history of the tvvo maids of More-clacke vvith the life and simple maner of Iohn in the hospitall. Played by the Children of the Kings Maiesties Reuels. VVritten by Robert Armin, seruant to the Kings most excellent Maiestie.
The history of the two maids of More-clacke.
History of the two maids of More-clacke.
titleStmt.author: Armin, Robert, fl. 1610.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by N[icholas] O[kes] for Thomas Archer, and is to be sold at his shop in Popes-head Pallace,

div.p: The history of the two maids of More-clack, with the life and simple manner of John in the hospital. Played by the children of the King's majesty's revels. Written by Robert Armin, servant to the Kings most excellent majesty.
London, printed by N. O. for Thomas archer, and is to be sold at his shop in Popes-head palace, 1609.

div.head: To the friendly peruser.
div.p: Gentlemen, citizens, rustics, or quis non, I have boldly put into your hands, a historical discourse, acted by the boys of the revels, which perchance in part was sometime acted more naturally in the city, if not in the hole. Howsoever I commit it into your hands to be scanned, and you shall find verse, as well blank, as crank, yet in the prose let it pass for currant, I would have again enacted John myself, but tempora mutantur in illis, and I cannot do as I would, I have therefore thought good to divulge him thus being my old acquaintance, lack, whose life I knew, and whose remembrance I presume by appearance likely. Wherein I whilom pleased: and being requested both of court and city, to show him in private, I have therefore printed him in public, wishing thus much to every one, so delighting, I might put life into this picture, and naturally act him to your better contents; but since it may not be, my entreaty is, that you would accept this dumb show, and be well wishing to the substance.

closer.signed: Yours ever as he is merry and frolic, Robert Armin.

div.head: The history of the two maids of More-clack. With the life and simple manner of John i'the hospital.
div.stage: Enter a maid strowing flowers, and a serving man perfuming the door.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Strow, strew.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The muskadine stays for the bride at church,
sp.l: The priest and Hymen's ceremonies tend
To make them man and wife.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: By my maidenhead a joyful time, I'll pave their
Way with flowers.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: While I perfume.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Some say this widow's rich.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I will not say as poor as Job, but as bare as January, when the trees look like a girl, whose colour comes and goes as frost does in the milk.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: 'Twas wont to be a rich widow and a poor knight, but now false, a knight rich and the widow poor.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: however honour is most rich, no matter who is poor.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I would my fortune were no worse

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Thine may be better.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: So much if't be thy will, if ever knight were guled, be it in me, in me I pray.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: What are the waits of London come?

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Play in their highest key then.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sound hoboys.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Make the god's dance ▪ cause jovial mirth
Music in heaven for this earth's marriage
Is a triumphant concord to us all,
To me 'tis sealed by promise for his daughter,
Who in our blood shall sympathize, says I,
She shall be ours, bedded, although some
Menace a rivalship, yet the sure card
Gives the trick ours, and we shall win,
Since in my mother it doth first begin.

div.stage: Enter the solemn show of the marriage, sir William Vergir, Earl, lords, auditor, sir Rafe, sir Robert towers, Filbon, others.
Enter lady, mistress Marry, mistress Tabitha, and some other women for show.
Enter James a citizen, father to Humil.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: A good one to thyself, to us 'tis seasoned,

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: A marriage sir?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I and a good one friend.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Because 'tis rich.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Good reach at stars, i'faith 'tis true.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: In whom sit, if I may be bold.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: A knight of More-clack to a London widow.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: My burdened soul says I, a knight of More-clack to the widow Humil, just, 'tis she,

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: By this the blessing of the holy rights,
Relishes in them, they are married, at least
Fair for it, I must witness to't, farewell.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: How ignorance pleads nonage, in his eye
He knows me not, 'tis not the lion's kind,
Whose nature challenges right property.
Of perfect being, if it were,
Humil would Humil know, that him begotten,
To be what now he is married again,
And her first husband living, blame her not,
'Tis my own project, thank my letters,
That falsified our deaths black funeral,
Into her mournful hearing, follow it,
Think on thy soul, divide that bitter band,
Knit by the closure of a mutual hand.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: I rest ye sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: At whose suit Wat?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: At the bridegrooms, I'll not a foot further till I have eased my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: No nor I, we are asses right, we carry provender, but are not the better for't.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Thou'lt not believe breads bread, till it be tasted, I say to thee, in this trunk is provender.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Be an ass till thou prove it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Here's money which will buy it.

sp.speaker: Wat
sp.l: O by a figure, I say to thee thou art an ass.
How?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: By thy burden.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: No otherwise, that's not so good.

sp.speaker: Vvat.
sp.l: Because thou hast ears.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are all asses that have ears?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Are all trunks laden with money that are heavy?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Indeed I confess in that I am an ass, but I think so.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: By such a surmise thou makest it provender.
sp.p: We are watermen, and think because we see a man coming, and that I am his first man, he'll be my first fare, when another gets him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Come, you are bookish.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: And thou blockish, say rights right, and no more.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: See sirrah Mr. Touch, what an officer?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.l: Yes, he's booking in, Mr. Touch, salve, sis salve.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Jubio tesalucre, have.

sp.speaker: Vvat.
sp.l: He hears us not.

sp.speaker: Tuch.
sp.l: Let me see capons, turkeys, small-birds, beeves,
Muttons, partridge, plover, wood cocks.

sp.speaker: Vvat.
sp.l: Meaning us, good morning, and many sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And many Mr. Touch.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Are ye come water-squirts, are ye come?

sp.speaker: Vvat.
sp.l: And why sir, water-squirts?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Because you shoot water, and so do they, but ha ye that will do't, my dainty element dashers.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Do't and stand to't Mr. Touch. if we might spend it sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Well said honest knaves, bear in, but say where's John i'th hospital, and's nurse?

sp.speaker: Vvat.
sp.l: At hand sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: 'Tis well, away, and Touch touch the tips of their tongues, with our seller suckets.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I'll touch the tips of their tongues, and their tongues tips, I'll baste their bellies and their lips till we have jerked the cat with our three whips.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Married? 'tis ended, and the next pull mine.
sp.p: At a fair fleece, a golden one, the eldest daughter is my hope, what then rests in it, oh you winged lapwings, farthest cry, when we come nearest to't. Quando pecus omnia sub umbra ruminat antiquos paulilum vocitamus amores.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: 'Tis done too late to ask why so.
Tardy intrusion as a cipher placed.
Fills but up room, while substance in the other
Makes number precious, I am that round oh,
Which with a sigh, as sad as is my soul,
Grieve all too late, what now befits my moan,
But black despair, and die in't do,
To make thyself known, but represents
Mellow fruit falling into danger, o I am that
Rotten ruined, and unrelished substance,
Which on my own upgrowing tree falls off,
By the time's negligence, undone I am,
Would I had died indeed, and not in word.
These ill tuned words like discords sounded harsh
And yet were thought true music, well, well,
I'll take my stand, and as she passes by
Note if her glories dash not all my hopes
With base forgetfulness of what she was,
My picture can she not forget, may be,
Old love may yet live in this newborn lady.

div.stage: Enter the solemn order of the bridegroom's return from church, and as the bride goes by, she beholds James the citizen with earnest eye, and speaks aside.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am wonder strocken in myself,
Oh you all-seeing, pardon my attempt,
My second choice hath laid siege to my soul,
And my disloyalty hath in that witness
Slain the concurrences of after joy,
Even so he looked that had my maiden heart,
Even such was he, whose far estranged death
Gave me this licence of ill liberty,
To do, and undo, oh forgive me then,
Weak in my sect, my fault to the best of men.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: New wedded lady, and our morning's bride,
What is't that troubles ye?

div.stage: Lets fall her glove, James takes it up.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.l: A loss but being small.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: No matter for the loss.
You find a purchase, equals any cross.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Let it go then.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: She knows me and this constant accident
Subscribes to't, how can she excuse,
This double deed, this false neglect of love?
O women how you dally in your trust,
How quickly you forget late living life,
And bury the remembrance in your smiles
All ye this morning for the dead to sigh,
And shed your tears in bosom of new choice
How have I sifted your loose difference,
For ever being precedent against all.
Glad am I at this opportunity,
Who landed me even in the jaws of fear
Swallowing my destine happiness
To utter ruin of herself and me
If the unconstant air whistle abroad,
That Humil lives, than Humil's widow dies
In desperate scandal, racked and tormented,
In the remembrance of old wretchedness,
Which to prevent, plots cunningly contrived
Must buckler my repute so weakly wived.

div.stage: Enter sir Robert towers, and young Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Lost her glove?
So she makes known.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: I'll find it to my everliving glory,
And the next triumph, wear it in my helm
Daring all gallants in defence to approve,
S. William Vergir's lady owes this glove.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: If my good fortune challenge such account,
To find it by my friend or industry,
I'll prick it on a pole, and with my lance,
Curvet with nimble speed, in course of arms,
And as I snatch it by a curious pass,
Cry in loud echo, here is for her love,
Who on her wedding day did lose this glove.

div.stage: Enter the two maiden sisters, Marry and Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: The bride, our new made mother lost her glove.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: I sister, so she says.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I'll seek no further, for it is in vain.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Especially when quicker eyes than ours,
Arch in the brows of loves two votaries,
Lord how they'll brag to find it questionless,
'Twill prove a ransom of a thousand kisses,
Amorous glances, modest courtesy,
Oh how these flatterers can insinuate,
And stretch an inch of length to an el of wide
Here's much in office for a little pay.
A glove God wot.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I sister, so they say, go to ye wanton you
He that shall marry thee, is matched i'faith,
To English rash, or to a Dutch snaphance,
You will strike fire with words —

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Who I? now as I live sweet Moll.
If Filbon marry me, as by this light.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And wink.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: 'Tis hard to juggle with the devil, we maids
So simper in each others quantity
As we know fashion ere it be devised
Forswear you one, and I'll forswear —

sp.speaker: Marry.
sp.l: The other, just even so,
Shall I be plain with thee —

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: You'll answer, no

sp.speaker: Marry.
sp.l: I. Tab. no I. Marry. I no.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: I know you will not, therefore let him go;
I love my Filbon as men love good clothes,
Put them on every day.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: And I love towers as I love my sleep,
Embracing thus, folding most dear.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: Your lover nightly, as you wish him yearly.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: In troth in such a sort:

sp.speaker: Tabith,
sp.l: As children play with stones, to make them sport.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: You make me blush Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: At the thing ye wish,
Plague on the cat that loves nor milk nor fish.
We are all maiden's pictures, fain we would,
Yet we cry away away, when away we should.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Yet again.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: Never yet.
Ever so when so our matters fit.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: They are returned, a glove or no.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: No, but the glove I sought not, I ha' found.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Where is't man?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: You're the glove, which still I seek to wear
Make me happy, match it to a pair.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Be these for ever matches.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: How can ye find the glove was never lost?

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: By seeking you that lost not what we find.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Indeed a willing loss, is loss of gain,
Where loving finders pity losers' pain,
I will not say, enjoy so much the rather,
Because gift giver cries out on the father.
But if I durst, I would, till when.
Unmatch our gloves, each take his own again.

div.stage: Enter sir William, James, Earl of tumult, auditor, sir Rafe.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: It is enacted by the bride's fair word,
Who finds her glove, is this day's governor.
To manage all our pastimes in the house,
And thou art he, the only conqueror,
Of prize and honour, then enjoy it.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: You give and I receive, is this my office?

sp.speaker: S. will.
sp.l: Signed and delivered.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: I take it on me, music triumphs come,
Since fortune cast her favours in my fist,
I'll be most prodigal.
Yet with modesty I am a citizen.
Unlooked for welcome, and unthinking come,
To receive honour in a state's man's room.
Yet to this presence I will still address,
Love, pains and duty in this business.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: In this is fortune blind, whose deeds are dangers,
Giving her graces not to friends but strangers.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Prove on my fortunes howsoe'er they stand,
I hold my fairest fortune in my hand.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: The like do I.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: And all the fairest fortunes I would prove,
Is only this, to enjoy my dearest love.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.l: The like I wish.

sp.speaker: Humyl.
sp.l: All happiness live in thy choice, in hers
sp.p: All mischiefs, horror, les ourself participate in tender of our choice, freely delivered in the fight of heaven.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Humyl.
sp.l: The wedding dinner breathes his last.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: And we will visit it; on forward there.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: So fair and fortunate to be thus false,
Wedded to two. O you all wondering eyes,
Gaze till your fire flame, your eyeballs drop
In moist imagination of this act,
Before the first be dead to wed a second. o

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why writ you dead in your last letters?
Sick was I, and no likelihood of life.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: What then, was that a just excuse
To varnish over this base counterfeiting? no,
I'll make it known.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I care not, I will thus excuse it,
All opposite of injury was yours,
Putting to test our weakness by your letters,
Which carrying credit, woman in her will,
Guiltless is causer of this open ill.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Had I been thus advised, but all too late
sp.p: Acquainted with your speed, I had prevented what now is past and done.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why did you not? Bawd to your own misdeed,
three quarters guilty of this accident,
That might and would not stop the hazard,
Will ye now heap up miracle,
And make it worse in note, by adding to't
A bavins blaze, 'tis not so soon extinct,
Being fierce of flame, quenched must it be,
By watercourse of sounder policy.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: I am from myself in this, what shall I do?
O I am mad, and mischief menace is unwitting of all purpose.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Why did I cast my glove,
Proclaimed the finder stickler of our sports,
But to a point prevailing practice?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: I know not how.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Leave all to me, women that wade in sin,
Have their wits-charter to authorise it,
And they have antidotes that to digest,
Which better judgements lose themselves in, let me alone.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: To lie with him the while.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis true to lie with him, but not in sheets,
To use the flourish of a woman's skill,
In winds and turnings, other lying,
My new made husband injures not the old,
As I am simply false, I will be found
Constant to death, knowing my business
Is to heal up the fractures of the time,
And to salve virtue in her taint of ill.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: I build on this.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Some month.
While I possess the glory of my name;
Attendances according, marry our son
Unto his eldest daughter, that's the point
Of all: regain my jointure next,
'Tis not amiss to satisfy your debts.
These two achieved, the third is bedding,
and if this brain beguile him not of that,
Say I am single: no, since blame sits nigh,
Behooves give care to use true policy.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Our son.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Aside.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Mother the noble guest expects ye,
The present meeting does neglect itself
Where our fair bride is wanting,
Pray come in, you do them wrong.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am not well, and this commanding air
Retains my health, I came to fetch it,
Wherefore enriched with what was ours before,
We yield fresh duty and attend them.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Will you be mindful of our marriage, mother?
Begin so happily in yours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I shall endeavour in it, come.

div.stage: Enter Marry. Tabithe, towers and Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tabithe.
sp.l: Close and hushed, not a fly stirring,
While they feed hungerly, we, that loves detie
Does proclaim pardon to presume, and speak,
Challenge liberty, now by my maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: Swear not love.

sp.speaker: Tabithe.
sp.p: Can you forbid my oath? Sir I will swear, and till I lack it, say, naught shall confine me, I had rather feast in fancy's pittance, then to seed gauged with attention, soothing every bit with curiosity: no, I can fill my belly in a minute, satisfy my stomach in a breath: lovers digest their sighs, and chow their spleen, while other appetites fall hungry to't, and let them greedily graze on.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: What's all this?

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Louers talk any thing.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: I understand ye not.

sp.speaker: Tabithe.
sp.l: I would not that you should, for I speak greek.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Regard her not, for she talks, idly Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.l: Be you advised then sister, I'm a fool.
Yet not so simple but I talk by rule,
I say, dine they that list, I will not, for my dish
Dressed to my hand is here, here let me feed,
'Tis the maid's modicum, God send us speed.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: In that I claim a part,
Whoever feeds this dish hath Mary's heart.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.l: So then said I well, ye wicked thing.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Mot as I am of lovers union,
Contracted to a solitary life.
By thus retaining singleness of heart:
Changing all doubts that the world affords
But one, so to thy sweetest self,
Which only art idea of my thoughts:
I vow a reconciled amity,
Which violated, does command my life
To yield his interest to the shade of death,
May be, your father alienates our choice,
And shows as sunshine threatening rain,
To the all-hoping harvest present.
Which to make clear, the honourable word
And fatherly regard in present office
Have passed their speed in our attention.
I know your father will receive their onset
Soldier-like, joying the siege begun,
Which though resisted, bids them gladly come.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Pause in that trust, give ear.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Sound proclamation,
It is enacted by the bride and bridegroom,
And by ourself chief in authority,
That all receive their pleasures
From the most high in this assembly
To the lowest, all pastimes are made free,
Dancing, carding, dicing revelling.
And other dues oft-times fit merriments,
— unto the bride and bridegrooms health.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: The days short, and the night's

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Stop there.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: I will, to pleasure thee,

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: There take your places.
And in your sweetest key of music strokes
Sound pleasant melody, echo those sounds
Which true-love-hearts, in concord's chiefest grounds
Have their blest being, use art in times,
Which may give welcome to our noblest guests.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: We are betrayed, young Humil is at hand,
Dance, and excuse it so.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Sound music there.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Content, a dance, and in again.
Content, no dance, yet in again.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: It is ungently done to snatch her so.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I snatch but that which promise says is mine,
Have I offended?

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Right what is wrong.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Here,
Or where you dare, go seek in Brainford, go.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Brainford?

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.l: Put up, or I shall be offending unto one,
Against the bride's son, dare ye?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I repent not what is done, come you with me.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: So slaves by violence do hurry hence,
The rights of —

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Peace, we on you do impose command.
Yield duty in it: hall, a hall there.
Music sound, and to the bride do consecrate this round.

div.stage: Enter all the train to dance.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Squire of the day, cull out your gadding bucks.
Select your light-heeled does, open your labits,
sp.p: Turn them to the toils; we that are Venus' huntsmen may partake the sports.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: You're a gallant woodman sir.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.l: My son for one.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe,
sp.l: And mine the other.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Good my daughters for them both,
sp.p: A course or so, go too, lead on, the bucks that have employment for these does, are not these giddy gamesters, I'll be the forester and look to't.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Hear you that?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: A lightning before heat.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Your father's air is herald to his tongue.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.p: 'A knows the coat, but thinks not who shall wear it.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: There's two and two.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: A couple more, too makes no show, our measure is for three.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.l: Why then the bride.

sp.speaker: S. Kafe
sp.l: And bridegroom.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: O sir, pardon me.
My joints were oiled to pleasure, but now, not.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Then I with her.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: You! O, your authority commands her.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: It gives his luster light.

sp.speaker: James
sp.l: My warrant wins, where his dos lose the right.

div.stage: Humil snatches Mary from towers and dances.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: My son in law grows bold.
Good again, here's much to do in love,
One simply stands, not challenging his own:
And reason, marry, chance is yet unknown
No, nor in you sir, though my son,
Words passed contrive, but after deeds cry done.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.l: Brookest thou this disgrace.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: O sir, no remedy, what justice lives so free.
And to her own is friending,

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.l: I am mad to think on't boy, but — ▪

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: How goddess-like the elder of the two,
Stations the measure, it is a jovial sight,
Where beauty gilds the pavement with her light.
How sullen Saturn took her by the hand.
With frosty feeling, in whose joy touch,
She shrunk her hold, but with a jealous eye,
She glanced on me, fearful that standers by
Should be enriched with't: now she smiles me fair,
Guilding my torture with an after hope.
Thus moralized, I season on my right,
Her love thus challenged by inferior might.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: After this dalliance here comes other sport.
Pray ye attend him gallants: how now John?
Tardi venientis John, you must be whipped.
Quaeso preceptor, non est tibi quid.

div.stage: Enter John, nurse, boy, all in blue coats.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: This silly sot, my lord, so please you hear him,
Utters much hope of matter, but small gain.
An old wife nursed him, which we call blind ales.
She dying, left him to the cities keeping.
Which in their hospital they thus nursed up.
Amongst the bounties of their other deeds:
Many besides, now you shall hear his fellow
Ask him such questions as his simpleness
Answers to any: sirrah let me hear ye.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: John, how many parts of speech be there?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Eight, the vocative, and ablative, caret nominativo o,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What say you to radish Jack?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: That it does bite, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Where ha' you been Jack?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: At Paul's friend.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Who saw you there?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Mr. Deane Nowel, oh he's a good man truly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What did 'a give thee Jack?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: A groat, look here else.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What wil't do with it?
Carry't home to my nurse.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I'll give thee a point Jack, what wil't do with it?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Carry't home to my nurse.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I'll give thee a fool's head Jack, what wilt do with it?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Carry't home to my nurse,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Carry a fool's head, what a fool are thou?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Should I go home without it? whose fool now?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Who tolls the bell for John?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I know not,

div.stage: John toles the bell, at if 'a pulled the rope.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: When died 'a?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: E'en now,

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Hoo jack ho,

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: My nurse's chicken. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: A silly ignorant, is a ever so?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Never otherwise, a cleanly idiot, what's put on him in his morning rises, is as you see it. This old woman is his nurse.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: So please your honour you are sent for to the court,
The court goes from Richmond to Whitehall.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: We will attend her, kind sir William Vergir.
Our times bridegroom to yourself and you.
We wish as we have ever done, all love,
sp.p: And for our present entertainment rest indebted to your bounty, if a court's amends have in it power of satisfaction, you command it, this acknowledged ever, your poor acquaintance but an honourable friend.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.l: We will attend your coach.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Sir, be mindful of our servant Filbon.
What wants in him to weigh down love with gold,
Our savours shall supply.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis a light weight, their portions if they, poise no better, will to the world's belief, grow less not greater, but let them pass, I weigh them as they are. Come nurse, follow us John.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p:
Wipe your nose, fie a sloven still, look ye be mannerly, hold up your chin, let me see ye make your holiday leg, so my chucking, that's a good lamb, do not cry for
any thing, John if ye do.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: No nurse, grace a god, grace a Queen.

div.stage: Enter sir William and his lady.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Shriek no more in my ear, I prithee peace, I grant I made such promise: but what then, shall I for that so set her on the rack, when her fair fortunes look a better way, with the small proffer of your giddy son, no: you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You'll let me have my jointure yet.

sp.speaker: S. will.
sp.l: Yes that, three hundred by the year 'tis thine,
But for your son to wed my eldest daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, he doth merit her in my accord, and 'tis no wrong in you, to dip her blood in the self die that we are in.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I grant his merit, but her shining value made golden glittering, by my wantings looks to a higher promintoria, from which four, when your son gazes, it affrights him, yields him planet stroke.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He shall not have her then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Believe it wife.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: He shall.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I will not bed with you till then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ha' said it, and when posture of our word takes his base being, I will die the death, into our wedding sheets shall mischief come, before my body break your word with me, even on your wedding day.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Nay then up with the lists, again it shall not be.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I care not, think you I do, keep your word in that, when I break mine.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: No more, be stranger to my bed, do do. Have
I of nothing made thee much and wilt thou —

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Yes I will, have you of protestations, oaths, and vows made these loose fractures: lawful be it then for me to shun the make-peace bed, since strife sets such division
betwixt man and wife, I am most firm in't.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Very well, 'tis not amiss.

div.stage: Enter auditor, sir Raph, towers, Filbon, and their sons.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.l: The night draws on, 'tis time to part.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: At your pleasures gentlemen.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Your gallant daughters will be next.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Or not at all, for I am past it now.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: And we are prayed unto, our sons are gentlemen,
What resteth then, but we sail nearer to the point?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: What point?

sp.speaker: S. Ra.
sp.l: Of marriage past, betwixt us in our promises.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Indeed to one I promised her weight in gold, unto the other which I love as dear, her weight in silver, now gentlemen what goods have you to equal these large promises?

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Why all we have.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: But 'twill not serve,
The big avouchments of my promises
Controls you all, and all men's else, ye all,
Under degrees of Earls, lords, or as potent
To toll them on I echo these large sums.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Unvalued must your sums be to such choice,
Honour looks high above such petty price.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Look honour high as heaven,
Our earthly reach doth level in that eye,
And with the imbellishment of richer worth
I'll by, and outbuy the imprisond scope,
Of reaching blood, what will not value do
Where strong ability dos reach his hand,
And they have beauty too, which joined to riches
Will proffer fair: though not so quaint
As courtly dames or earth's bright treading stars,
They are maids of More-clack, homely milk-bowl things,
Such as I love and fain would marry well.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: It was a promise in you to be kind.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p:
I'll forward with that promise, you love
my eldest. —

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: With my soul.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: And pity to divide that love, then harken me,
When she's dead and lives again, she's yours, not till then,

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Then never but in death.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: You love my youngest daughter.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: And will ever.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Pray ye do: but when you are from yourself a woman, she is yours in marriage.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Woman to woman joined 'twere wonderful, but in more maze of wonder I should be, what I do challenge to participate, and from myself live to divide in other.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Faith not till such a wonder.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Is't not enough to scandal thy true word?
But are we slighted thus with fantasies,
Impossibilities, dead and alive again,
Manhood infused in woman: 'tis not generous.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.l: Come son upon my blessing
Take from thy eyes thy heart adoring shine,
Offer no more thy altar bearing thoughts
To one so giantlike, whose reach sits high,
Above the compass of a gentle eye.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: You have your answers, gallants.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: We like it not.

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Nor will we so except it.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Forewarn come near my house,
Rapes, felonies, and what may else be thought on,
I will with heavy impositions
Surcharge ye with, if not with pistol shot,
I will defend myself and these I keep.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Live I to hear this?

sp.speaker: Fil.
sp.l: Convey them from him, let us.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: In disguise.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: Or not at all.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: That way or none ▪

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: James, when I put thee from my thought, let me be hoodwinked from all, fortune, thy partaking gentleness is such, as I do love thee, troth I do.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: God continue this good league.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Wotest what news?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: The lovers are expulsed, and my fair hopes shine the clearer: what wilt say when I do marry this knights eldest daughter?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: That you are then possessed.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: She is mine contracted in her father's word.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: New broken sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: 'Tis true your mother challenged it: but he as angry as the raging morn, whose choler breathing shakes high battlements, puts her off with a pause of contrary, I know it sir, her jointure is subscribed too, which else to do, sooner should earth to heaven presume a progress, than the grant make firm what the antecedent challenges, your mother upon this abandons from his bed, vowing bold absence, he enraged, gives way to all malign and stubborn fashion of contempt, such a close today never had practice, such a wedding night, till this sad first never had purchase: you shall well agree them sir, to atone this jar, use means I pray you, 'twill become ye, well, when wrangling wrestles with such violent injury, 'tis the son's office.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: 'Tis the devil's office and not mine, to hell obedience, if he break his word.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: You had a father loved ye better.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: He loud me as a King in a play, his servant who were seeing him gives kind applause, but small utility: my father in my childhood loud and left me to the world's eye, in bold necessity, I thank him for it, since he died my mother hath her chance, mine wants the proof, stand by time's minion and inconstancy, o.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Have patience.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Yes, whereunto? sith all my hopes lie level
With despair, such milksops in whose breasts,
Lingers a lagging hope, to them is patience sufferable;
But to me, horror, and hell's black motions tickles
Me on to mischief, and I will —

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: So.
Now swims upon the main, such shipwreck-souls,
As the winds rage splits on the rocks of danger.
Ay, my wife, and son all three, now heave, and
Fear of sinking, makes us timorous.
Should we be shelving on the shallow beach,
The seas rough gusts might scatter our intents,
So idle purchase might be gathered up,
From our so sudden shipwreck: no my state
Stands yet secure: though maimed yet is not foiled:
But salved by wise occasion may make good
This sudden overflow of tide and flood.

div.stage: Enter John i'th hospital, and a bluecoat boy with him.

sp.speaker: Boy. and John.
sp.l: Where hadst this bread and butter?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: The crow did give it me.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: But take heed the kite take't not from thee.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I'll choke first.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: John shall's play at counter-hole i ▪ th' cloister?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I ha' ne'er a counter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I'll give thee one for a point.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Do, and I'll play hose go down, oh sir, Willy is a good man truly, here's good custard and capon, and good bread and butter too.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Now John, I'll cry first.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: And I'll cry lag. I was in hobly's hole.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I ha' won this John, now for another.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I'll hate again will I will ô.

sp.speaker: N●●se.
sp.l: What's the matter, making my sweet lamb cry?
sp.p: Come John we must to London, on with your clean muckender, and take leave of sir William and his lady. God's me your point, where is it John?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: The crow has it, and did win it at counter hole.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.p: I'll whip ye for it, take him up, lose your point lamb, fie, up with him sirrah.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Good nurse now, no more truly o, o

sp.speaker: Ferris.
sp.l: Where's this suck-egg, where's Jack a boy:
Come ye movable matron, where's this tuggage,
Away away.

sp.speaker: Nurse,
sp.l: I'll take leave of s. William and go away.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Now my John juggler, your nose is like Lothbery conduit, that always runs waste.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: What's his name John?
Sternigogilus, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A goggle eye, a wanton eye, a madcap, so a means.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Wat?

sp.speaker: Vvat.
sp.l: Hollo.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Trim boat. turn head, we're at hand mushroom,
We come boy, we come.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Come John, our leave is taken.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Have o'er the sea to florida, and was not good King
Salomon, tom Tyler.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O well sung nightingale, a board a board there, ha rip there.

div.stage: Enter towers in a tawny coat like a tinker, and his boy with budget and staff, towers tincks upon his pan drinking.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Boy, you understand me, though the liquor have renst me, remember your business boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes master.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.p: 'Tis rare to be a tinker boy, work enough, wench enough, and drink enough, is't not boy?
sp.l: I master.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Boy where shall's have doings, I'll clout any woman's cauldrons, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Master, tincke on 'tis time, for we ha' ne'er a penny.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Pawn budget boy, I'll ring in boy, hay any work for a tinker, a ti, ti, tinker.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: By my maidenhead 'tis he, the merry tinker of Twitnam boy, is't not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes flower it'h frying pan, he stops holes well ▪ 'tis he,

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: Has his old songs still, has he not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes, and new to boot.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: And be not these tinker's knaves? upon their backs they bear a long pick, with a staff it'h end,
sp.l: He shall ha' work, I'll break way for him, and
Call out the gentlewoman to hear him sing.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Let them all say what they can dainty come thou to me.
We shall ha' work master.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Draw boy, homo armatus, boy, I'll pepper your pans,
Where's my dog boy?

div.stage: Enter s. William Humil, lady Marry, Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Your dame has him, and will meet you at Putney.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: Indeed what's a tinker with out's wench, staff and dog.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Is this the tinker you talk on?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I madam of Twitnam, I have seen him lick out burning fire brands with's tongue, drink two pence from the bottom of a full pottle of ale, fight with a masty, and stroke his moustaches with his bloody bittē fist, and sing as merrily as the sobrest chorister.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: Come tinker, stop, mend.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: I'll tickle your holes.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: He's out of tune for singing now.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.p: Out of tune and temper too, thus can dainty liquor do. Sing boy.

sp.speaker: Boy,
sp.p: Relish master, relish, a note above eta master, sol. fa, me, re.

lg.head: Toures sings.
lg.l: Unto herself she made great moan,
And she looked green as any leek:
Her friends did ask her cause of care;
But she cried out in her despair.
O stone, stone ne ra, stone na ne ra, stone.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: Cold comfort in a stone.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Doctors came her pulse to feel,
And surgeons with their tools of steel,
To dig, to delve, to find her pain,
But all they did it was in vain,
Still on her back this maiden lies,
And with an open throat she cries.
O stone, stone na ne ra, stone ne na ne ra stone.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: Better and better by my slipper.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Old wives they made answer thus,
Green sickness was most dangerous.
And oatmeal eating is a food,
That never yet did maiden good.
Tut, tut, tut, 'tis nothing so,
Still she cried out with pain and woe.
O stone, stone ne na ne ra, stone ne na ne ra, stone
Till she was delivered of a chopping boy, and all
Was as I am, omne bene.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: What a disfiguring diet, drunkenness,
Lays upon man, a beastly appetite.
Lingers the body where such gluttonous means,
Swelters in surfeit of desire and ease.
I am an enemy to myself, to think,
That man is slave so to continual drink.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Knight, feast, knight, a good cellar keeper knight.
I'll cusse thy daughter knight.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Shall's not buss knight, shall's not neb?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Thou art in the straits Moll, and the pirate's shot will sink thee, therefore yield.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: I am thy towers, being thus disguised,
Am come to steal thee, then be sudden Moll.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Nay then i'faith.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Knight shall's drink at door like beggars? no, I'll in knight see thy seller, is thy seller in dept, knight dare he not show his face? your black jacks are my elder brothers, knight, shall's not shake hands with our brother's knight?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Follow him, look he steal nothing.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.l: Tinkers steal naught but drink and maidenheads,
I'll watch him for one, if you allow loss of the other.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Where's Touch?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Who wait you on?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: On the world sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: And what says the world to ye?

div.stage: Give her the letter as she talks.

sp.speaker: Tutch,
sp.l: To me sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: To you sir, what a message? letters, ha, daughter I'll be your secretary, nay hide not, juggle not with me, I'll once be secret to your thoughts, i'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: 'Tis a card of lace sir, which he bought me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: I bonelace sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Bonelace subscribed too like a letter, lace weaved of ten bones, is't so? even so.
sp.l: O Touch.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: O mistress now am I tried on my own touch,
I am true mettle one way, but counterfeit another:
Oh life no life, but mess of public wrong,
Day turn tonight , for I ha' lived too long.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: From Filbon.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Yes from Filbon, woe to the day, time, and hour.

sp.speaker: Tabi.
sp.l: Wherefore.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: That I brought this news from your lover therefore.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Pull off your coat.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I need not sir, 'tis ready to fall off, yet if I do, 'tis the time of year, the fall of leaf sir, and serving men do drop their coats, there sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Begone, come no more near my house, if thou do thou art a felon, are you the carrier, are ye indeed, must love make you his mercury, must Filbon send by you? my own betray my own, to him, your a knave, they shuffle ye about, I'll deal the cards and cut ye from the deck, you understand me, go.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Gang is the word, and hang is the worst, we are even, I owe you no service, and you owe me no wages, short tale to make, the summer's day is long, the winter nights be short, and brick-kiln beds dos hide our heads, as spittle fields report.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Wife coop up our guinea hen, that wants this treading, you gossip, to your closer, Filbon shall, if we want will, yes yes what else.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Come daughter.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: I deny Filbon to his face, bring me to him, I will justify that all his actions are like apricots, they dangle and love them.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: You do.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Alas sir, mistress Mary is with the tinker gone, and at the back door horsed, I see the gelding, 'twas a dapple grey.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Hell and damnation.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Death and torture.

sp.speaker: Ta.
sp.l: Christmas gambols, father, shooing the wild mare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Am I a jest to laugh at now, indeed, indeed.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: O not so fast sir, I am for your race, and will out strip ye, if ye run no faster, speak what was this tinker?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Tinker sir.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Ay, thy master.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: My master is a knight, who jove-like in the shape of such a thing, came to see Danae in this shower of gold.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Toures was it?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Etiam, ita, ego I sir.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Now fortune at the fairest, go with thee, thou hast been coming in this stratagem, and I do give thee joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: You do housewife.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Wishing a whirlwind in the like disguise.
Fetch me hence smoothly, I am lawful price.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Where's James?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: At London.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I will thither too, since the devil drives I am the second, lock her up, safe be it your charge.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: What for this counsellor, concealing rape and ruin of your child?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Whip him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I shall never endure it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Unless you do betray this trust, and tell us to what cabinet he hath conducted her.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: To Putney, o to Putney sir, where they'll be married.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: At my parsonage, God amen, no other hospital to shadow them but mine, am I the patron of so hard mischance, that my own of my own shall cozen me, I'll thither, son your company?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: No, I'll to Richmond sir, prevent them there.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No sir, you shall with me, that's the next office, for yourself, delaying due, in other all things ready, you will then serve yourself, nor he nor you shall carve so to your appetites.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Your pleasure sir.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: For my sake turned away.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Yes, my master turns a new leaf, and so must I sir, 'twas for your letters sake.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: Is there no hope?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: What do you call it when the ball sir hits the stool?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: Why out.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Even so am I, out, out of all hope ever to come in to crumb my portage at his table sir.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Welcome to mine, then honest Tutch, but speak thy mind, thinkest thou she will continue firm?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Firm sir, yes, unless you take her for a join stool. she'll continue firm, she seedes on ye, dreams on ye, hopes on ye, and relies on ye, telling her father what a friend you are, protesting and molesting to the hole house of your good parts, vowing to God and man if she have not you, she will have nothing: for any man's pleasure, she'll not line if not for yours.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: I stand resolved.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: She wishes that ye should, or she'll not trust to ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Rafe.
sp.l: Son seest thou young towers?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Not since our last repulse in love, since when I stand affected unto singleness of life.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: Then art thou stable in my thoughts, but let me whisper to thee boy, young towers in a tanker's habit hath her stolen, to whom his hearty adorations were to this hour consecrate, she's gone, and her old doting father got to complain him at the court, how 'twill work I know not.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Like wax; she'll take any impression, sir she.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: Like a tinker say ye?

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Certainly even so.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: 'Twas my own project father, he applauded it, knowing my fashion of that counterfeit, to be so sure, as no man could forgo me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: But himself sir, 'tis a point of law, arraign him upon ipse facto.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: And art thou stepped beyond me? where tonight thou slepst: soft be thy pillow: easy be thy rest, and may thy bed be.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Mortal down, thistle soft,
She laid herself under to keep him aloft,
And ever she said, come turn thee to me,
And was not this bonny lass Mary amber?

div.stage: Enter auditor, and doth whisper with sir Rafe.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Marry indeed she hath resigned to me hard choice,
Near am I but as arrows afar off,
Seems to the shooter neighbour to the mark,
Till it prove otherwise, so I
Furthest from favour am, though seeming nigh.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Change your mark, shoot at a white, will say, come stick me in the clout sir, her white is black, 'tis crept into her eye, and wenches with black eyes the white's turned up are but as custards, though they seem stone cold, yet greedily attempted, burning hot, and such a wench is she sir.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: I know she loves me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Most affectionately burns in desire for ye; but key cold through her father, she stands to freeze while others are appointed to thaw the ice, not you.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: I must use policy.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: The only man, I will assist you sir,

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: I thank thee, and I will prevail in't.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: I think sir, if I see my house tonight , there will come warrants to make open way to their recovery, thinking they are with me, whom I protest I have, not seen, and unacquainted with her subtle stealth, am now as clear as is the babe new born, I neither knew of it, nor where they are, I do beshrew their hearts, right I have in him for it.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p:
Sleep in my house then, so my word shall make your answer stronger, I have a son, I wish him so possessed, but not with violence, yet say he do climb high, and reach the top bough with a stricter course, I knowing not the manner nor the means, acquits me, and God give,
them joy, my oath is clear, and that's my warrant.

sp.speaker: Audit.
sp.p: Sir, I will trouble you to nigh, by this sad time his moan doth challenge comfort, and the council whose loves he hath so often visited, heartened on by the Earl of tumults means, they will add present purpose as he begs it.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: But if the Earl know of my sons discharge, signed by his careless answer, 'twould allay his hot endeavours with a cold responsal; but cease that, the time shall come — —

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.p: 'Tis mine, the cause and all, pine let me in them, if the son of hope shine as a troubled meteor in the sky; 'tis our fate's fortune, and no matter cause no remedy.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: True vauntings of resolve, 'tis late, and custom challenges no right in me, to be so hurtful to myself, the evenings's air is raw and cold.

sp.speaker: S. Raf.
sp.l: Filbon follow us, be you more temperate.
You see what hurry threatenings this misdeed
Wounds deep are dangerous, though they hardly bleed

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Sir, I am lessoned,

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: As the boys at school?
Practice their knowledge by contrary rule.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O I am slain with wonder.
Hath this life left in it a little breath,
To blow out treason, reek ye clouds of shame,
Putrify all imagination, hold her at stern,
There let her sink, never to win again,
Homer's recovery, shall I say and think it?
O —
Have I not been in bed tonight , and so
Talk idly wanting sleep, or rose from rest,
As many troubled do, acting like life,
Awaking dead, for in that flattering fear,
Perchance her reputation may be saved.
No I am certain in my fear, 'tis true,
In yond black closet lies a wicked woman,
(I will not say my mother, that names lost)
in the twinned brazings of the slave her man.
In James his arms, and shall I suffer it?
O —
To blab, it were to herald out my shame,
In quartered scutcheon of black obloquy,
To murder one were most impartial;
Again to turn hills on this sin,
Would write me bawd, but to be nobly satisfied
Is a content licenced from equity.
The knight shall know it, I will write to him,
Startle his bold imagination with pale fear,
Rose his revengeful spirit on them both,
And make me hopeful of his love neglected,
Forgive me world, heaven's justice puts me on,
And though a son, I'll punish both or none.

div.stage: Enter Earl, and lord, and sir William, the lords, and sir William's two men bearing torches.

sp.speaker: Earl
sp.l: You that bind up in secrets of the night,
Day's benefits going to rest;
As peaceful birds, lodged in a sanctuary.
Smile at our courtier's care, whose industry,
Rules in the silent and all shadowing night,
Suits that are breathless in a troubled day.
Have their abiding in our cares at night.
Hard censured, and atoned by late advice,
Salving the world's scares, as we would your care
Knew we the burden of it.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: With us the morn is mated with the moon
And we are retrograde to what you do.
Esteeming conscience, benefit and good.
Challenged in service of our country:
Sir though our blood affirm us labour free,
It binds thee more to busy industry,
Wonder not at our late upsitting therefore.

sp.speaker: S. Vil.
sp.l: Your humour's toil in our extremities,
But we unthankful merit contrary,
think it a want and weakness in our kind,
I post and labour in a toil myself,
Seeking my own: midnight to me is noon,
And all the hours of dull past night,
Sunshine eclipses, that do much molest me,
Pardon me that am so tedious.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Seeking your own.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: My eldest daughter is conveyed from me,
Hurried away, as thieves by violence
Convey their booties from the true man's store.
Auditor, towers son hath done this deed,
A rescue noble lords.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Rescue and right, challenge the benefit.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: A warrant for a general search,
Restraints for cinck-ports, and all passages,
That thinish water doth despoil us of.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: It shall be signed i'th morning,
Draw the contents as you affect the means,
And let attendance urge the early act.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Good night.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Good morrow is it not?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Betwixt them both.
The moral of my misery seeking too late,
That to recover which I lost too soon.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And yet in each you stand indifferent.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: I must, till perfected by you,
Either late loss, or timely victory,
Recovering what I fear is past advantage.

sp.speaker: Ear.
sp.l: Hope the best sir, things at worst,
Season in their decay, as children mend,
Bent in their eye to ruin, yet they pause
Resting in grace, does reobtain at will,
Opinion in rash judgement, dooming ill.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Good rest, for we go to't.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: The peace of happiness be with ye,
I will retire me to my inn, and wish.
Hours as short as momentary breath,
For till the morning, minutes hours be,
And hours years, such is revenged to me,
Might I enjoy it?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: My man, a midnight messenger, what is thy haste in leath steeped, speak is that all one? one all, that we call daughter, gone too, is she?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Wherefore starest thou so wildly, say, wert thou asleep and wakened? comest to us here without thy better part? and sent abroad, leaving thy wits at home.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your son sir, in all haste sends you his tales, wishes your wit and judgement suddenly, read and regard sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Give the torch, if you will see my mother and your wife, fellowed in bed make haste, James your man writes on your pillow etc. my eyes are witnesses to their adultery.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.l: What's the news?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Plague on these jauntings, once we shall be old, and then this trotting life will linger in our bones, all hours are our nights, we dally with our own destruction.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: It cannot be, or if, or if, what if? if it be so I am undone, poisoned am I with fair promises, no marvel though you do forswear my bed, if yet again, if what make I here when treason is at home, away.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: The bird that greets the dawning of the day,
Signs with his wings, the midnight's parture,
And the sleet dew moistening the cheeks
Of morrows welcome: gives earnest of the morn:
Yet all secure, adulterate lust dos sleep,
And I the hatched young of this trodden hen,
Stands sentinel to her idolatry.
Blow you swelled winds and crack the battlements,
Rouse their incestuous luxury with fear
Of what's to come, yet that were my mishap,
no silent air fan on them bawdy breath.
That as they reek in their licentious love,
Devil may seal sure, and Morpheus so pleased,
May to their pastime add affliction
Delivered by the hand of him that's wronged,
And stands indebted to his destiny:
Yet are they as the hour, whose sandy minutes
Runs out at pleasure till the period comes,
Fast sleeping, and enjoy their quiet,
Rouse the black mischief from thy ebben cell,
Land in the bosoms of this twin in lust,
Him whose heaped-wrong calls vengeance to be just.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Lock fast that door and leave me. Give me your light, son Humil?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Father.

div.stage: Enter sir William and his men.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Thou seest I am obedient at thy call. Exit servants.
I come as messengers that bring their bale,
Signed in their looks, be well advised,
Thou makest a challenge goes beyond all grace,
Should it be false.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: It is my love to you that makes me step
Heart-deep in disobedience to my mother.
Wretch that I am to think her so,
It makes me desperate of priority,
Fore thinking my beginning to be base,
Conceived in such mistrust and frailty,
My front hath that impression still,
Adding a blush to my distemperature,
And I am crestfallen in sanguinity,
Pray ye believe me, would it were not so.

sp.speaker: S. will
sp.l: Enough watch and be secret, I will enter,
Sit as the night raven or the shrieking owl,
Over my portal, menacing ill chance
To all within: for death is to my blood
A blessing, while this fever kills,
Almost my intellect or better part,
yet she's thy mother, and no son but hates
His own disgrace so highly merited,
And I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Sir, truth is truth, my conscience and religion
Binds up in me, and since I do proclaim
Detraction from my blood, by her misdeed,
Give me leave to report a fly a fly,
If it offend the virtue of mine eye.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: 'Tis true.
And yet methinks it should not be,
How hardly will this scandal take impression,
Where resolved christianity dos dwell?
But I will try the gold, perhaps 'tis base,
Who knows the heart's affection by the face.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Scarlet is scarlet, and her sin blood red,
Will not be washed hence with a sea of water,
Is this my hand, or is the fire fire?
Whose scorching heat dissolves relēting mettle,
Whenas it tries the substance; yes, and I
Make known my mother is an alien,
From my blood, so to fall off, and perish
Even in her pride of bliss, damned be the slave
That so attempts her spotless chastity
To ruin, I know that yet smooth look,
Plotted, contrived, and won her with device,
She never knew a double character till now,
But single singler she ever ruled,
Even modesty herself, Vesta resigned to her,
And virtue hand in hand at barleybreak,
Ran the swift course, none but a hound of hell,
Hunted this fawn of fortune to his kennel,
But my mother, forgetting her degree,
Dos captivate love, life and liberty,
By one deeds practise, wicked, nay far worse,
Fatal disgrace, honours created course.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Fool, fool, fool.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Light bubble swell and break, wouldst thou believe all this, and give a gloss to slanders cruelty: ripening reproach itself with thy fond ear, o Humil, Humil.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.p: Thou art a villain, and hast cast up hills against heaven itself: when sons unto their mothers are so false, oh where is grace? hoodwinked from honour, shamed to show her face.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Is it not so?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Trust thy own eyes, go, thou shalt see a sight
Will melt thy stubborn spleen in pity,
Sweetly she sleeps, whose innocent respect
Smiles in her dreams, the childlike govern,
Laughing loud in their simplicity,
While waking, mischief seeks that to undo,
Which true required, stands centinel unto,
Go and return with shame.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: With shame, devil of mischance what's this?
Did I not see their cutted guilt look big?
Was I in trance of my belief, ha, was I?
Can be no juggling in it: can there?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: No thou art constant as the Northern star,
And I as giddy as the untamed leopard,
That sees no means but dire destruction,
Flinging his foam to poison in his way
Man's mischief, plotted to his overthrow:
He told me true, oh that I live to think so,
Or they so wretched to deserve the thought,
Soundly they slept, whose slumbers killed me waking,
Yet to recover half slain reputation,
Done have I, what to purpose practiseth
If it prevail, our honour so reserved
Will kick at all malignant cruelty
That taints our name with ever living scorn,
Fortune be for me, I will that recover,
Which devil himself cries guilty too, my fame
the flight it wings, imps feathers of renown,
That left all's lost, my birthright tumbles down,

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Sir I am sorry.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: How can they excuse such wanton looseness, know they I stand here to thunder vengeance on their luxury.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: My mother's fast asleep, and I awake, am in a transive maze, unwitting how to make my peace with God herself and you.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Why are they not together?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Not in bed.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Thou shouldst with Argos hundred eyes,
Search in the chinks and corners round about,
It cannot be but she is extant there, ha, is she not?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.p: I am confounded in the search, please your justice be my torture, I have murdered innocence, sorrow is not the way, death is the least, I challenge cruelty and urge the exactest point of peril, slave that I am to live.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: A son, a son, to do so to a mother.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Fare ye well, rather than be a witness of my wrong,
I will not see myself in't, go thou worse then,
I'll sacrifice to the devil, that tempted thee, all thy
Distempered thoughts, cry mercy to her sects.
To spotless innocence be free, say all thy treasons,
Build on slippery ice, and thou art frozen cruelty,
Sir, for your wrongs, if you remit black torture 'tis
My hell, and I appeal to stern rigor, oh you sons,
Whose true obedience shines in majesty.
While mine more ugly than is vulcan's tithy.
Smells ranker than despised hemlock
Curse and ban him, I am your subject to't
And every mother, whose snow innocence,
Feels soft and tender, as the down on palm,
Rate my rebellion with a blissless name,
And for my sake give misadventure aim.
Guide 'em to me, say I am such a son,
Through whom a mother is so soon undone,

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Let me not see the while thou liv'st away,
Let thy repentance show itself in this,
Not to be seen where thou hast done amiss.
Caitiff depart.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: I will; this tongue that slandered,

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Be her slander still.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: It is too much already, was I bewitched,
That thus at hood-man blind I dallied
With her I honoured? O you times how have you
Nursed me, but no more, Humil hath branded on his
Mother's name, an Ethiop's blackness, and
A spotted stain, forgive me that and all.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: What need I to afflict revenge on him
That on himself exasperates, farewell thou pride
Of sons, who to a father in supposition only and
By law, art all so loving, that thy mother dallying
With wantonness as girls with gauds, thou not respects
The womb that brought thee forth, but ill attempting
So, and so thou rumour'st, as the fault ripe in act,
Is blown to air, and though her son thou
Utterest what they were, thou shalt not lose by't
Now it fits, I challenge from the offence some right,
And add confine to this adultery
Wife, wife, rise and come forth.

div.stage: Enter lady, in her night gown, and night attire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Call ye sir?

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Yes, take my closet key, let forth your lover,
Give me some ease by way of reason yet, and 'twill
Allay our discontent, oh God so new to marriage, and
So stale, couldst thou so soon revolt, so soon, ha?

div.stage: Enter James unready, in his nightcap, garterless with the lady.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: I must acknowledge all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O no, some better looze,
this will but add to mischief torture
Use patience now be reconciled to fear,
Be dovelike humble, and leave that to me.

sp.speaker: Jame.
sp.l: How can I, when the brand is on my brow,
But by exclaim, give ease to torture,
My brain is scared, and I am lifeless in't?

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Kneel not.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: A sentence, let us die.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: No marvel though you vow this abstinence
When deputed by him, you shun my bed,
You do deserve your jointure well,
To admit a fellow in a true man's place,
I thank ye for it, yes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: No, no words I know you can allege,
The devil has scripture for his damned ill,
And this dos neighbour it, go and attire ye.
Be smilefull, and express no grief in scythes,
Rather be tickling sportful, topped in pleasure.
Then daunted any way, that me concerns.
To use the madman's guise, but I am past it,
Since what is done, no reference hath to wish,
I am for credit's sake, supportable, all's well,
Content am I to be sensible, and feel my
Fortunes as I may, ranking myself with such,
As sometime lived in my repute most base,
Faith all is well believe it, I am satisfied:
I know you do repent, and that's my remedy,
Other amends I look not for, in, and attire ye,
But stay you with me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am obedient.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: Go thou shame, never till now possessed,
And in a breath confounded, sir, you see your wrongs
Shine through the herne, as candles in the eve,
To light out others, think you this misdeed,
Merits salvation?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: I must acknowledge contrary.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.p: Wilt thou for all this spite, yet use me kindly in the next?

sp.speaker: Iames
sp.l: Command me sir.

sp.speaker: S. 〈◊〉
sp.l: No● 〈◊〉 the second, this mistake me not,
Ratl. to bind thee from it, if here after,
Fashion of frailty summon us to fear
I must be plain, and therefore thus:
Look whensoever I hold up this finger,
Signing my lips with it, and cry begone,
Even then be speedy to depart the land.
If not, all power of mischief that I can, I will
And so resolve.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Sir, I am ready to the minute.

sp.speaker: S. wi.
sp.l: It may be, other reasons will restrain me
As causeless motives, nor seeing guiltiness.
sp.p: In needy sequences perhaps our heart will in itself bake truce with this mischance, or if it do not, yet attend our spleen, it will be better for ye,

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: In humble duty.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.p: Go, give copies of good countenance to our friends, think an is well, for so it is, I that am all in grief, am all in suffering, I forgive the reason, fare ye well.
sp.l: What I will do, is barred up in this closer,
The key that opens it, is my revenge.
Turned by a hand whose palm does itch with fire
Till all consume, a cuckold, cuckold William sir is
Its even so, would I were yet the last or least,
But not by thousands go too then, am I all alone, in this
Who is't that tongue calls man
That is assured of his wife's conditions ▪
None, or if any, there the phoenix lives
Unfellowed, be his fate renowned while mine
Is mockery, and a jestive stock, to all that knows me.
O you stars blaze fire, till this abuse be quenched
By my desire.

div.stage: Enter Tutch like a Welsh knight, and Filbon as a servant waiting.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Hark ye morris.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: I sir.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Where is Tailor? dudge me, will knog his pad,
What is chirken with cold button done, say you.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.p: Excellent, this is Welsh indeed, oh my honest Tutch.
sp.l: Sauce box, roly-poly , am I not your master?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: You are sir, pray ye pardon me.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: You must have your left eye diameter wise,
Fixed on my right heel, and all the offices,
A servant owes in duty to his master, perform
As naturally as if the forty shilling time
sp.p: Were come, left I leave talking Welsh, and crack your pate in English.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: I shall obey sir.

div.stage: Enter m. auditor in a merchant's habit, with Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Fairest of beauties, love her seemly self,
For thy two eyes are Cupid's, which do shoot
From thy enamoured bow, shafts all of gold,
Headed with mettle of immortal propose.
In thy fair bosom lives two hearts relenting,
Thine penetrable, through atoning pity,
Mine longing by desire to scale the fort
Of love's fair presence, make me happy,
Sign to my suit, but ye, for 'tis thy censure
Makes me thus bold, pronounce fair judgement,
Either of life or death, I that plead love,
Doubly devoted, challenge from thy deity
A maiden answer, let it come bright fire,
To try the substance of my loves resolve.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Sir, in sooth and verity believe me,
That I am fair 'tis credible, but to shoot
Arrows, whose heads have such immortal proof,
'Tis most erroneous and false, 'sfoot your a Puritan,
a citizen I'm sure, her canvas curran bags,
Stuffed with sweet cinnamon and cloves,
Good sir you are deceived in me, I'm country plain
Without this nicety, and do you love me, yes?
Then crave an answer without ceremony,
Fetched from proud Ovid in his arte amandi.
I do not like it I.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Bless you latie.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Sir and you, tell me of Cupid's eyes,
sp.p: Shot from enamoured bows with hearts relenting, doubly devoted, and I know not what.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Bless you virgin.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: No sir no, give me plain courtesy,
Drawing on love's white hand a glove of warmth,
Not chevril, stretching to such profanation,
You overthrow love's deity in this,
And putrify his altars with bad breath.
I am a dairy housewife, no such wanton,
So easily flattered with far fetched replies.
Yet I esteem this worthless person free,
And though not fair, yet something fortunate.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Hark ye now latie.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Sir cry you mercy.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Was a knight, marg you, of english in Wales, welsh blood, and 'tis no mock in en to marry in welsh blood, is it?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sir all the smiles a modest maid, can in this kind make proffer of, are yours, in your fair welcome, blame me not, though his unkindness made me negligent in your kind entertain.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Neglect me so.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Wiues unto citizens are tradesmen's daughters,
I am a blood of gentle composition,
My mind dos equal it, I must be coached.
Banqueted everywhere , courted abroad,
At home flattered, for my private use,
I must have fancies, playfellows, as apes,
Monkeys, baboons, muffs, fans, receipts,
Costly abiliments of several suits,
Will ye give this? 'twill break you sir,
And crack your credits fair condition, no,
Citizens would, but cannot answer so.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Hark you, marry with her, and God dudge me, all is yours, was a knight have land, and a great deal of riches, will maintain you well, say you.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: This gentleman or this, before a citizen, you sir pardon me I will ha' none.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: Then whom you will, call you this modesty to be so waspish? given to slight men off with incivility, give me leave to remember.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: What you please, all the world except one or two, my eye motes that trouble but my sight. Filbon for me, man else but mere illusion and idolatry, vain worship, images of molten mettle, which to dross dissolved, appear as nothing to my judgement, but his worth beyond compare, gentle and suffering as the silent air, that though it brook the buffets of base breath, yet in itself 'tis heavenly, free from earth.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Hark you, was knight in house called sir William Perger.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Verger sir?

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Morris was say true, give a ducat, look you tuck it, is mark, mark you that, and mark is 13 shillings four pence, good current money, and how do you? well, when was sir Robert Morgan, mik you latie, grace a God.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: You sir.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Was I lie pray you?

div.stage: Enter sir William, sir Rafe, Henry, a priest of Putney.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Think you master auditor, knew nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rafe.
sp.l: Upon my soul I think it.
I did wind him subtly as hounds the game,
sp.p: New got on foot, for instance he lamented oft his sons proceedings, neglecting his own house, lest you in quest of her should search it, believe me sir I tell you what I know.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: 'Tis likely, sons in these doting days
Will from their fathers alienate, differ still
From love's obedience, and in heart's affection,
Join hand to hand, though beggary neighbour it,
And let them go.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Sir I am free then from your fear.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: I good sir Henry I was wrong informed,
I am your patron in all love.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Long may ye line, so sir I find you gentle,
And a good benefactor to poor scholars,
We ha' few such, many we rather have,
That sell the church rights, then maintain them,
And in my next stanza, I shall tickle them.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Speak conscience and no more.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Nay as for that sir pardon me,
I seldom exercise without that thought,
What my text leads me to, I will pronounce,
Maugre the devil of judgement.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Soft.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Bless you gallant knight, a merchant sir,
sp.p: Of London am I, my estate secure, and so it please you covet this fair maid in marriage, nothing else.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Know you him sir Rafe?

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: Not well sir, but by guess, he is indifferent rich, has broke three times, made his head hole by means, and that say I, as this world shapes, is secure policy, what think you sir?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: I do not think it so, though common practice finds it furthering shifts, do the devil resemble, and bankrupt baseness makes good credit tremble, like it not.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.p:
Please you aunt, harg you now, knight was love this virgin, and God will, must make her wife, shall be her laty,
go in Wales, great worship God willing.

sp.speaker: Sir Vvil.
sp.l: O know this knight, he was created tother day.

sp.speaker: S Raf.
sp.p: Sir Rober Morgan, o sir, such a one, whose reputation reacheth to the best, merits a good conjunction, were't my daughter, she should have him, o beware when majesty shines in a man's estate.
sp.l: They long stand firm, spread wide regenerate
And though base born, yet honour makes them swell,
Like clustered grapes, till mature sweetness brings,
Lussio us conclusion.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.l: I have some mind to him, sir you receive
Kind welcome, let it store your thoughts with
Those sweet motions lovers wish to enjoy, she may,
Perchance, all things concluded on, before ye.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.l: Was a clad man, morris fetch trunk of 'parel
Was lie here a four week, will not out now.
Was welcome, plague on you, was love ye.

sp.speaker: S Wil.
sp.p: Sir, as for you, being city proud, my daughter's look sits on a courtier's brow, what sayest my girl?

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: O sir, a courtier on my life, I love to sit up late,
Lie long it'h morning, rot with sweet meats, and
To play at shuttlecock, methinks the games now
In my arms, in any hand a courtier's wife and
Why not? his black jet shows best about
Beauty's neck, and I am proud of such
A suitor, if I understand not his Welsh, like
A good piece of ordinance, I shall lie fast upon the
Bulwark, and discharge my obedient English
Must be a lady sir.

sp.speaker: S Vvil.
sp.l: Yet welcome sir, let it not grieve you.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Signior no, you're welcome to the wife I woo,

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: And mistress, might I be the man to strike the stroke.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: You, or else none, sir Henry.
