sp.speaker: S Vvill.
sp.p: Troth she says true, but listen me for that, come gallants enter with me, we will feast, there's little labour lost, where trial bids presumption scare the coast.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Right to a hair, 'tis mine, and I must do't
I see my fees, my rich advantage, sirrah boy,
Shall we have work, in faith and shall we?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Conclude, I'll busy him, sir Rafe.

sp.speaker: S. Raf.
sp.l: Son, you see to what a happy issue this disguise
Speaks fair, you know the plots, boldly proceed,
'Tis ours in action, but your own the deed, I must
Shun all suspicion by my presence, look to't boy.
If thou failest now, for ever lose thy joy.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.l: Ha, ha, master, I a Welshman, a hangman.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: A trick now on my maidenhead, I did mistrust it, come leave the rest to me, this priest shall marry us incontinent.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Ay, if I were the Welshman.
Because your father gave him light thereto.
sp.p: Therefore come sirrah, we'll shift clothes, meet us at Putney as my father shall mistrust ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Rafe.
sp.l: I will, excusing your departure till anon,

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Do gentle love.
Heaven on our venture smiles, this to approve.

sp.speaker: Tabit.
sp.l: O it cannot choose.
Fathers are fortunate in this good news.
Go ye drones, ye do not love the hive,
There's honey in't, 'tis a sweet thing to win.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I must break the ice for ye, if I slip up to the chin, now you will pull me out, save me from drowning mistress.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Fear it not.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I would be loath betwixt Welsh and English, to be hanged, mistress, I cannot live on the bargain, come sir, I'll shift with them, and now I must shift with you.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: I clothes, good Tutch.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: And use me no worse being your man, than I used you, being mine.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: O better, better.

sp.speaker: Tutc.
sp.l: O love, thou art a beggar, yet I am thy debtor.

div.stage: Enter two sailors with a trunk, wherein is mistress Mary in her winding sheet, others with pickax and spades, as on the sands.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Set down the heaviest load
That ever true affection underwent,
To you 'tis like the anchor of your ship,
Heavy at first, but easily weighed seems light,
To me, that not supports her bodies weight,
'Tis heart deep in the burden, and too ponderous
Sad, heavy is that load, whose leaden poise,
Is as a sullen sorrow, too, too pressing.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Sir, I would wish you to be brief.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Dig ho this golden beach, whose glittering sands
Shows with the sun ▪ as diamonds set in gold,
Fitly entombs a jewel of much worth,
Whose living beauty stained all lapidary.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: She was most gentle which was worth all riches.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: And this night's tempest did a cruel deed,
To take from me a value of such price.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: Sir, though our seas kill women with their frowns us their bugbear threats are womanish, and so we leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: Leaving yourself and all, sometime,

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Even so, no safer in our beds,
Or on the land, but under deaths black stroke,
And he that is the surest, sits in state,
Dyingly tended by the hand of fate.

sp.speaker: Tour.
sp.l: And yet methinks death should not
Take her from me, being scarce mine own.
But newly wed, never bedded yet.
So that the ceremony burning bright,
Hymen yet hath his tapers flaming red.
And the bold boastings of that good man's breath.
That all religiously made one of two.
Hardly disgesled in the freezing cold,
Little I thought the priest's word being, ever,
Should find his period in so short a time.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Sir, but the gift was given ye on condition,
Till death depart, better or worse,
Methinks this catechising little needs,
To humane guiding, and to you the less
Knowing what openly you do confess.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Bear wi' me master, he that pines in grief,
Lives as you sailors do, thinking at sea,
Every storm ends, when flattery flouts ye,
So to our lovesick sorrow comes a calm,
By ease of fancies, when 'tis furthest,
And many times the weapon that doth wound,
Is salve, and surgeon both, to make all sound.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Are ye ready sir?

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: All fitted, let me take my last farewell,
I am all jelly in my tears and sighs,
Wasted by waiting her untimely loss,
So long I did consume in drops of woe,
That contrary I laugh to think it so.
He that weeps much, having no tears to spend,
Smiles out the rest, but inwardly does rend,
Oh God that I venturing so hard a chance,
Should lose my dice, before my hand be out,
'Tis even so, in all things man intends
The loss is ours, the winnings not our friends.

sp.speaker: Mr
sp.l: For charity be brief, should the wind
Turn his beak into the Southern side
Our ship would leave us, dally not with grief,
Once and no more, let sorrow rule as chief.

sp.speaker: Tou.
sp.l: Then thus, and this the last,
Moll, I take leave yet on thy hearsed self,
Dead self, and self slain. Moll dice
I am thy morning music, call thee up,
To wedded rights, I lead thee to the church,
And there receive thee, dine with thee at noon,
Dance all the after day, bring thee at night
Into the wedding chamber, this is it.
And here I leave thee to thy virgin slumber,
Never attempted, as thy birth bestowed,
Madam beginning, take it in thy end,
So live thus die, only my married friend,
And nothing else, gone art thou to a power,
Which will with welcomes take thee, left I am
To the world's cross, thy father who enraged,
Will bitterly revenge thy death on me,
But I will prove his martyr, se-thee Moll,
Fool that I am to say so, here is all,
Gowns, tire, all abiliments of thine,
No rag shall rest remembrant in my view.
To stir the embers of thy dying fire,
I kiss thy key cold corpse, and with this key,
Lock thee for ever up, farewell, farewell,
My mouth the church, my voice thy
Parting knell. All cares that live and hear
This bell to toll, christian-like bid peace unto
Her soul.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Amen, be speedy mates, see ye not, look
The blueness of you cloud dos threaten wind,
If it rise fair, we shall be lodged in France,
But not where please the fates.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: A board, a board, hey.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.l: Hollo, linger no time aboard, you hear
With me ho, will the rest stay? how a year?
O God that man should leave behind,
And live, the love of soul and mind.

div.stage: Exeunt, and leave the pickaxe and spades behind. Enter governor and a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.l: Sir, welcome to Scilly,
Where I command my brother's friends have welcome,
But now my flattery gets you on this beach,
Where you prospectively see many countries,
Learn this of me, where danger shoots her string,
We in our neighbour nearness ought to fear:
but armed by our foresight, make bold resist
Against the brags of foreign enemies.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: I have not seen a better glass to look in,
What country call you you, whose cliffs are as the clouds
Smoke, and all shadowing mists?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sir that is France, a fair beseeming friend,
On yonder continent stands Ireland,
On this side Britain, and on that side Garsie,
Lands besides of much hostility,
Which are as sunshine, sometimes splendous,
Anon disposed to altering frailty.
We that all neighbour must so strength our being,
As fearless we may frolic yet not seeing.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: I understand ye sir.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Now let my longing have content in you,
With the report of them you lately saw,
My brother Vergir and his children,
Is he a widower still at More-clack?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Married sir unto a London cast a way,
One whose decaied husband left to live,
(Though poorly) yet your brother's lady.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: It is his choice, and I subscribed to't,
But for his daughter's sir?

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Alas, in them is he unhappy,
One is hailed from him by stolen practises,
The other lives as though she were not his,
A goodly gentle woman, but her own in heart,
She will be gone to, for her government
Stands upon will, as men stand on the beach,
Seeing the sea wherein they must be drowned,
Yet fearless venture on the ruthless main,
She will regardless of her father, marry,
And dos as most, long for the misery,
Signed to them in their cradles.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Sorry am I.
Ha, what scrambled ends heap up confusedly?
New digged and ripped up is this plot of ground,
Some shipwreck on my life, hid to deceive
The Queen and me of our advantages.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Likely sir,
And see our sudden coming scared from hence,
In the new ending, such as piled this heap,
Behind them have they left their implements
Which did the theft, what think ye sir if we
Redig the ground, should we depart and leave it?
At midnight would they fetch their borrowings.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I like your purpose, I'll make one.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: What do you think it is sir?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Nobody buried, it is sure some goods,
Wracked on the sea, money or rich commodity.

sp.speaker: Gentleman.
sp.l: Tobacco then.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: 'Tis likely, for with us men smoke their lands through their nostrils, shall I tell ye sir, 'tis a commodity may well be spared.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Good luck a god's name, sir it is a trunk.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Lift sir.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: 'Tis quick, it heaved as I heaved it.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.p: I'faith I think so to, in heart of hope I will be all so bold, as to break way.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: Ha.

div.stage: They break the trunk open, and she sits up.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: If you be men and born of that weak sex,
Which I myself profess, being woman,
Pity the living sorrow of a maid,
Buried for dead, but back again recalled,
By the divinity of heavenly power,
Amaze not, I am creature, flesh and blood,
Not as I see me, a pale and earthly ghost,
The story when you hear it shall make plain,
The woeful chance of life so lately slain.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I had acquaintance with this voice, my cousin.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.l: 'Tis she, sir, 'tis mistress Mary Virger, I know her.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: My name recalls my memory,
And I am such a creature, o,
My uncle, where am I? return again,
Death thou art wanton in a lover's pain.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Cousin I will not question the particulars,
The time calls on a present comfort,
And your life half spent,
Makes true necessity delay no longer,
Therefore come, as leisure we shall hear,
The dying story of your misery.
However , glad I am that such a chance,
Lāded in Scilly not in neighbouring France.

div.stage: Enter in Filbon in Welsh attire, and Tutch in servingman's, like one another, with them s. Rafe, m. auditor and Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: If ever you used speed, be swift as lightning,
Shoot as the stars in their celestial spheres,
Go and return as Paris did from Greece,
With that immatchless Helen, tell the priest
It must be done, he will believe your haste,
Because 'twas quickened with the former grant,
And promised by the knight himself.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Let me alone to make the way, follow you son.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: And if I do not let me lose my prize.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Where's the knight?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Busy with one, who comes as conjured up from Cupid's quiver, strooken deep in love, he is a apothecary.

sp.speaker: Tutch
sp.l: I know him his mother was a.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.l: Peace.
sp.p: Him will I busily attend, go you dispatch while I detain the father, if this prove, 'tis comic pleasure in the school of love.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: We must be quick and sudden, come.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Slip like your eel.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: If any man know any lawful cause why these two may not marry, now speak, or else for ever mum, I am gone i'faith.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: Master, remember, you ha' my tongue.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Yes, and thou mine, let me alone to counterfeit,

div.stage: Enter sir William with Humil, like a apothecary.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Think on your oath.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Sir, if I do not, let me die.
When I have poisoned her with this confection:
Be you cloudy killed with sorrow, 'tis a skin,
Will draw to purpose on the straitest glove,
But then your promised reward.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: My daughter and my goods,
I have no other son but you, all is thine,
Question not the reason, why this is,
For I have many, and amongst them one
Sites all the rest, that known to thee,
Will rather hasten death, then pity it.
Go, I will bid my guests, for to this feast:
Shall she have noble poison, 'twill cause fear,
Use less suspicion, and my mortal hate,
Shall itself kennel in the pride of state.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Give order for the banquet,

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Within there.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, what is your will?

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: To murder thee,

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: She dies sir, if I live, I am a apothecary.
And can knead the paste to purpose, she is gone
Had she a thousand lives laid up in one.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Wife, I must have thee paint,
And set a gloss upon this lovely front,
To move, and to attract all eyes look as the summer,
Which glads all hearts with his blood-creasing spring:
Use thy best graces, though most proudly
I will have it so, fit thee to all state,
Decked in thy choicest ornament, shine glow-worm,
In the noon of night, for at this supper.
I will have more than all our friends,
Music several, masques and revelings.
In which thou shalt be mounted as the bride,
And I the jolly bridegroom, will tend on thee,
As duty and the time commands me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Whereof comes this cost?

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Examine not, but lay your best end now to't
Council with this apothecary which I sent for
To the business, pray ye use your art:
For I am bent to this consumption,
Where's our servant James?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Within sir, shall I call him?

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: No, I will wait on him, for 'tis my duty.
Such as would spend in feasts, are but the slaves,
To attend the pleasures of consuming knaves.
And I am one of those, he is the flower
That I must crop too in this fatal hour.
Pray ye appoint sir, she will fit you well,
My purse shall purvey what you shall determine,
What we will be wasteful sometime, and our own,
We uncontrolled may dispose of: 'tis our love,
Rather our destiny, hate joined to this brow,
A horn that draws on death, no matter how.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, in my closet serve yourself with sugars, there are spices of the purest, use them in this cost, what else you want, please you command, they shall attend you.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: I want virtue in a mother, are you one?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I am a mother to an absent son,
But not to virtue wanting, wrong me not.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Wrong not yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I never will.

div.stage: He discovers himself to his mother.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: You have.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Humil, oh my shame and not my son.
By thee a mother is made miserable.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: By me black fin? no by thy own neglect, made perfect by my true intelligence, and however cunning masqued and donned the vizard that so muffled me, I knew not who was in the bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Your eyes were witnesses.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: And holy ones.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Found you the man you looked for?

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: No, 'twas a subtle strain, so hoodwinked truth,
sp.p: I am a traitor if I did not see James your man fast in your arms.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thou art a traitor then, if any James were there, he was no man of mine, he was thy father.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Marvel not, at leisure I will tell thee all,
His late return, the trick to place him here,
My stay, and his continuing in this house, which
Known, thou wilt no sin account, to keep our own.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: O you prophetic fairies, how dally you,
In concaves of our hearts, shamed at my error
I thought for ever to be from your sight,
But thinking, truth was blinded, I forethought
Some following business, thus I altered
Coming as one disguised to save her life,
Damned for that fact.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: My life?

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: You must be poisoned at this feast,
'Tis I must do the deed, o mother,
How are you blessed in my return from travel,
I that to light bring your offence, so thought,
Must be the pardon at your judgement brought.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ah me.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: No more, much secrecy calls on us,
Acquaint me with my father, plead my guilt.
We shall with cunning so unfold this business,
That our hopes shall strengthen as they perish,
No idle practice, but a serious toil,
Must bring home conquest from this long wished spoil.

div.stage: Enter Henry, Filbon, Tabitha, sir Rafe, Tutch.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: If I lock up this treason, let me perish,
No sir, my breast is yet an uncorrupt and holy house,
that harbours in it, naught but honesty, and to do
This wrong to my patron, per deum atque hominem fidem.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: No matter if you tell it now, 'tis done, finis men
Say, concludes the ancient work, and this
Though newly done, cries so be it.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: If keep secrets, can be but offence, and so 'tis now,
May be, I lose my place, but there's a friend which
Turning calls detraction, at his heels lives hope,
Whose cunning quickness every fault to favour.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Why true, and we shall as we may excuse it,
'Twas a deed done in Welch, you understood it not.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: Let me alone to buckler thee sir Henry.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Can ye ward yourself?

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: This was a pass, 'twas fencer's play, and for the after veny, let me use my skill.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: However girl, thou art my daughter now,
What thou shalt lose in father, from thy own,
Thou uncontrolled shalt find as much in his,
And I am he.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.p: And I acknowledge both this in my lord, my head, my husband, at whose bed I am obedient, at whose board I am obedient: all in all, I am the wife of Filbon, whose rough Welsh, hath got a constering English, parse it boy, nouns, pronouns, verbs, adverbs, and God give thee joy.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.l: With vocative o, your father hears it.

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: And ablative caret, takes his daughter.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Then in pluraliter, ah has a son.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: So singular and plural all is done.

div.stage: Enter auditor, like a merchant still.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: If ever you were swift be nimble now, what hay married, tide this knot?

sp.speaker: Tabith.
sp.l: Ay, and the earnest blow given, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.l: Sir, I have set my hand to't, sealed the deed,
Pray God it cancel not in me.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.l: Then part, and every one be silent.
There is a feast appointed at the knights.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Our marriage dinner, is it?

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.p: A gallant one, much cost is threatened. And the good old knight unbuckles from his back, the liberal load of honour, dos proclaim triumphs, and welcome unto all, calls for his wife, charges her care, commands his servant James to invite his guests, which in a roll stands quoted, there's a new come pothecary, and he bribes, even grace herself in this assembly, and dos promise his furtherance in the business, on the sudden you are missed, daggers and devils the knight cries where's my daughter? one up ascends to search the chambers, another runs to seek for this lost daughter. I knowing more than much in this her absence, singled myself to warn you of his search, hither will he come, for he fears young Filbon, missing the futers, calling for the merchant, I answered not (Being absent) in this heat: the Welsh man, where is he? none can be found, cries out he knows not what, and all his word is now, a plot, a plot, a plot.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: What will ye do?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Kiss and part, till fit occasion of our next salute, Filbon farewell, my husband think on me, I am thy treasure but thou bearest the key.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: I will home.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: And I will see the rest, what will you sir do?

sp.speaker: Henry.
sp.p: Nay I ha' done enough, I am undone in myself, hei mihi quod nullos, I must do this deed, 'twas I pauca the rest, I'll home sir, I.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: What rests for Welsh sir Robert Morgan, by God was crag de pen, and the hangman calls to me, da hum a, da hum a?

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: I will be at this feast in some disguise.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I'll fit ye sir, 'tis here, I am touch right, hic et ubique, everywhere .

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Now smiles the instant, and wraths wrinkles seem,
as smoothed curls upon a wanton stream,
My hopes grow big, and their delivery,
Is by our midwife time brought to true birth,
I will not be a pointing stock to th' world,
No, if this gossip rumor publish it,
It shall be christened with revenge and death,
Why when, are we grown sluggards now?
Tardy in bounty, shall we niggard it?

div.stage: Enter Humil in white sleeves and apron, and others posting over the stage with boxes.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: Be quick, carry those sweet meats in,
Bid them that in this business have to do,
That they attend this rich confectionary,
With no common care, the cost commands more love
And duty, sir we are fitting to occasion,
Would all your guests were come.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: 'Tis the feasts duty to attend,
Thou art a willing mischief, hast thou fitted
Our purpose to the proof?

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: Have I, think you I am slack?
Pushed on with hope of beauty and reward,
She dies had she a life more dear.
Then the last spring, sole comfort of the year.
But I will cover and prepare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Do, do, my daughters thine, my goods, my all,
Blessed beginning to my sorrow's fall.
Where's my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Here.

div.stage: Enter lady gallant and brave, while Humil and others prepare.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: That one so heavenly fair should earthly be,
Slave to misfortune, base in luxury.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir for to please your eye, I am thus quaint,
Good faith I am ashamed in myself.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: How and a woman.
Come blaze thy affections to immodesty,
And though thy virtues contradict the deed,
be Venus' wanton, smile, with Helen's eye,
For I will have it so.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I was not so brought up: I shall endeavour, though my cheeks put on sensible die of other bashfulness.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Sir your honourable guests are come.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nay then you wrong me most of all,
Show not these signs of fear, all's past,
And I am dead in old remembrance,
Troth I am, forget it, as I do, say on.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Coaches so fill the pavements of your door,
That scarce can passage give the footmen way,
'Tis not amiss you go to meet them sir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Why well said, spoken with courage, and I will,
Jovial like a bridegroom, lady you see,
They wait on us, and all attend on thee.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Worthless I am, but since it is your will,
I borrow light from sunshine of your beams,
Who glisters so, gives splendour nothing proud,
Darkened by fear, half hidden in a cloud.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nay hand in hand in faith James pardon me,
That dally with the darling of your heart.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Even so, but little thinking such a thing,
Small gain springs from that toil, where industry
Sweats in the brows of others victory.

sp.speaker: Hum.
sp.l: Father be mindful, this presuming knight,
Plays with the flame, burns in the candlelight,
When we shall furnish to disfurnish him,
Of what he yet enjoys.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Humil, 'tis cunningly contrived,
And I attend it.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.l: For charity be swift.
Place your plate, and pile your vitrial boles
Nest upon nest, these for wines and bear,
The other tend the call of altering diet,
Sirrah, quoth he, we shall fit I trow,

sp.speaker: S. will.
sp.l: Not well, James be gone.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Sir, you shall pardon me, unless with her being not well.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Think you I will; what leave my country, sir.
Upon a slight, a trifle, 'tis more dear to me.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Wast not thy promise?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Pughe.

sp.speaker: S. William.
sp.l: Pughe.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Madam, lean on me, I'll bring you to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Prithee daughter, faith I'm passing ill,
Your honour and the rest must bear with us,
'Tis nothing usual, a queasy fit.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: The mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No, the husband.
Good faith I am not woman sick, though woman
But earnest ill, clogged at the very stomach with
A sudden calm, I fear me 'tis my death.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Nurse help to bring her to her closet, do.

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: Excellent fit, supported by ●tod.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: Plague on't, shall I be left alone, master make haste? But 'tis my deed, I am author of this shift, he's where he would be now, I'm where I should be too, but not well backed, yes now I am.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: Besecke ye pardon me.

sp.speaker: Sir William,
sp.l: I am wronged, and to this company,
I make it known by coming of thy daughter:
Is my son made her indored husband, shall I
Suffer it, call you this courtesy, 'tis simple craft?
sp.p: Cloaked under thy denial, is this well to engraft with us unknown, and so to join yonkers to heirs, he is my only all, and married unto thy daughter?

sp.speaker: S. will.
sp.l: Ha, married? Nurse, how is't within?

sp.speaker: Filb.
sp.l: She's very ill sir, and I fear.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.p: That your disguise is known, come juggle not, call you this nurse? O thou dissembling boy.

sp.speaker: S. William.
sp.l: Are you married ▪

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sir I must needs confess it, he's my husband, and the reason?

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No matter for the reason, I ha' done, God boy ye, cony-catched by a trick, and so persuaded, good.

sp.speaker: S. Rafe.
sp.l: I am abused.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Yes questionless you are, I have all right.

sp.speaker: Filbon.
sp.l: You have no wrong sir, I to affirm your word,
When I was woman, and from man I should, and now,
I trust my shape dos challenge but your promise.

sp.speaker: Tutch.
sp.p: I played but John come kiss me now says she, I am Tutch your quondam servant sir, thrust out to thrust them in, a lawful marriage is no mockery sir, I counterfeited Welch, to join this constring English.

div.stage: Enter auditor and his son fours.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: What at a gaze sir William? cannot be recalled.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: No, no, more mischief, nay come all together, welcome.

sp.speaker: Auditor.
sp.l: Thank ye sir.
sp.p: My son returned, surrenders to your doom his life, for yours so lately lost, deputed in your daughter, for she is dead sir, buried in the isle of Scilly.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Not amiss, what's the next pagan? all the craft of this is known.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.p: Sir had I too hearts to melt this frozen fear, would thaw with passion, the drops distilled from our tormented brain, witnessed by these sailors that interred her, knows how I parted with her when she died.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Is mistress Mary dead?

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: She is.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Well, shall I have justice for her death?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Command it sir.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.p:
To prison with him them, for she is murdered, sir cause you knew your rapine and your theft, tied to your runaway legs that clog, you were uncertain of her portion and our love, therefore to rid that fear, you rid me thus of her (To me) most dear, my own, my only eldest of my
daughters, o.

sp.speaker: Audi.
sp.l: I'll be his bale.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.p: Sir tell not me of bale, for my assurance pleads in his life, and he shall die.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: You have no precedent for that.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Yes, remember Donnington's man, Grimes,
Who for an heir so stolen and married,
Was hanged, and the sergeant at arms
For assisting them, did lose his place,
If this were done, your theft will hardly scape.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: I thought of that indeed.

div.stage: Enter James and Humill disguised still.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Murder, murder, murder.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Ha, by whom?

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: By this fair counterfeit of husband, here's my witness, and the deputy in such a mischief.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: My wife is made away, poisoned here, and you that should be just are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: We follow, speak, explain this mystery.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Your wife sir.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.l: Yes, supposed for dead, as risen from my grave,
I came to More-clack, but a little late,
Even when the lying priest did call her thine,
She knew it, and devised with her glove,
To repossess me of the house she challenged.
sp.p: So honoured, I slept with my own, but thought the contrary, you know what happened, that son that so betrayed his parents thus disguised, fearing ensuing mischief, wrought by you to have poisoned his dear mother, 'twas your biding, therefore murder, but the will of heaven bade otherwise, and yet she lives, wife what say you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That all is so.

sp.speaker: Humil.
sp.p: And I affirm it true, my shape cast off dos answer ▪ sir in few.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.l: Pretty in faith, no marvel you forswore my bed,
when you had substance for a property,
Sir you must have your own, who can deny it?
And I must as the story runs be mum,
Fooled in myself by my own slights undone.
But what's this to my daughter, where is she?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.l: Brother Vergir.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Brother George from Scilly, what's the news?

sp.speaker: Governor.
sp.p: That your dear daughter dead and buried sir, by miracle was thus preserved, which at more leisure I shall manifest: pray ye forgive her fault, come there's some wanton blood left yet, says I, ye will I know, and wrongs passed all remedy, the world must undergo.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: My towers, the dead dos live, I am thy wife, Mary.

sp.speaker: Toures.
sp.l: Or her ghost, a shadow or a substance.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.p: Sister I will teach ye a medicine to make a shadow substance, lie with him tonight , as I will with my Filbon, and by the morning think but what is past, and you will reckon rightly you, he'll hold you three to one my medicine's true.

sp.speaker: S. Vvil.
sp.p: methinks I have a tickling in my blood crosses all anger, malediction hence, hence, thou ill tempered fear, this comical event seasons the true applause; since welcome is the word, i'faith, I know not what to say, fain I would, and yet a lazy lagging apprehends with doubt, but well I know not what, in me, it lies to punish or to pardon I will be general laughed at, once insooth I will. I am a widower, gallants, and you meet at marriages, and funerals, so think it pray ye, I abridge all compliment, bar all opponents, and resolve to favour you, you, you, and challenge from your lou, persuasion to this purpose, since our fate makes us the world's fond idiot, be it so youth, and your fortune was prodigious to it, and my best of spirit, binds up in this, all is but thankless merit.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.l: Then epilogue am I,
Imagine all the world were in your house,
And hearing this report with wondering brain ,
I thus excuse it, gentlemen you see how fortune
Favours in extremity, if any botched up ill, have
Show of good, and is not in thee sequel understood,
Yet bear with all, as this old knight has done,
Losing a wife redoubled in a son, what you shall
Want in judgment, seeing this, think every
Act is subject to amiss, so said, so done, will
Bring to true delight, hands meeting thus,
To sign this blessed night.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
